import React from "react"; import "./story.scss"; const Story = () => { return (

Our Story









We think of ourselves as hands-on curator. For us make is integral to our design philosophy. It is crucial how a piece of clothing feels when worn. Weâ€™ve always wanted clothes to be the way we drew them â€“ relaxed and lived in, a natural look. We find menâ€™s clothes interesting in their structure, feel and functionality. We started by designing menâ€™s clothes, and then found that women wanted them.

We're inspired by the authenticity we can find in nature, people and places, and we think it is the same quality we look for in the materials we choose. For example, the feel of hand-woven Harris tweed and the irregular slub of Irish linen. We feel passionate about landscape, and its connection with such fabrics and the skilled people who weave them.

We like to work with manufacturers who understand and share this passion for make and quality of fabric: specialists such as John Smedley in fine-gauge knitwear, Mackintosh and their part hand-made raincoats, and the Scottish knitting factories that continue their heritage of producing the best cashmere in the world.

We also find these qualities in other peopleâ€™s work. In 1970, We was encouraged by finding â€“ at a jumble sale â€“ an old, yet finely stitched pinstripe shirt. Today we still find it exciting to hunt out objects we consider to be well-made and enduring. In particular, mid-20th century products such as Anglepoise lamps, Ercol furniture, and Robert Welch stainless steel cutlery, represent the best of our heritage of timeless functional design. We enjoy pulling these threads of tradition, quality and skill together in clothes that are meant to be worn in the real world, where good design is about living with thoughtful style.

); }; export default Story;
